label: Letter from Olive Legendre, January 5, 1951
description: Letter from Olive Legendre to her sister-in-law, Gertrude Legendre, thanking her for the Christmas gifts and clothes she has sent, discussing travel plans and the relationship of her daughter, Kathy.

New Orleans,
January 5th.
Dearest Gertie,
What a Christmas you gave us! Such good cheese, absol-
utely marvelous, we feasted and feasted, and I love my
stunning red leather cigarette case. It matches a red
leather wallet you gave me Christmas a year ago---are you
psychic or is it good memory! Armant was tickled to death
with your presents to him and howled over the pill box
which you know damn well he needs, AND the [magazines] for
a year. He said he had written to you,and of course he
too is lapping up the marvelous cheese from Oregon. I
have had many compliments on my red leather cigarette
case and as the Victorians said "tis a constant reminder
of your thoughtfulness!" So many many thanks.
And many mary more for the lovely dresses you sent to me
before Christmas, and while I thanked you when you were
here I want to tell you again how welcome they were and
often are they worn. I caught [New Years Day] gathering up two of
them while -  she and Tobin were here for four days
and realized she is just as predatory as ever. I [s]creamed
hoarsely about a trousseau which left us flat broke and
she said trousseau dresses were very nice but she was a
little tired of them and anyway they are mostly spring
clothes. So we settled the situation by her promise just
to borrow one dress, I balked at two and said dress is -
to be returned come March 1st for Kathy to take with her
to New York to meet David Giray's plane on March 9th. You
may be seeing it [the dress] at Medway the latter part of March in
case you are still there---don't say I didn't warn you.
She said she'd like to spend a night in Aiken to intro-
duce him to Uncle M. and Aunt N. ard then drive over to
Medway for a day and night IF convenient with you when
the time comes. Thats a long way off so I'll write you
early in March to see whats what, or she could perhaps
phone you from Andalusia where she and the ["]British Sub-
ject["] will be spending a few days with the Biddles. Momma
has invited them to do this and I think its a good idea
to see the guy In a different environment, plus a four
day motor trip down here. Kathy plans to spend the first
night out of Andalusia at the Spur and Spoon, the next
in Aiken if Morris and Nancy will be there than are have
room for them, then Medway, ditto if convenient when the
time comes, the night after that in Atlanta with my good
friend Lily Minier, and then the next night they'll, God
willing, be here.
I told her she could spend three or four days in New York
[End Page 1]
when she meets his plane IF I can get her a room in the
Junior League Headquarters at the Waldorf which has very
reasonable rooms and is a sort of pseudo chaperoned place.
Its very hard to do this however since there are so many
demands for rooms from girls in Leagues all over tm U. S.
[due to their being reasonably priced no doubt, with break-
fast gratis] so, if she canft get a room there, do you or
Rose happen to know the name of any New York hotel which
has a sort of chaperoned se ction with reasonably priced
rooms for college age girls? If you or Rose do, would you
drop ns a card, just in the event the Waldorf section is
"Out?" No, on second thought, I'll wait to hear from the
Junior League at the Waldorf, yes or no, so don't bother un--
less I write to you again about it. I know its ridiculous 
to worry about such a place when I allowed my two bimbos
Anne and Kathy to travel all over Europe alone, but I don't
want Kathy criticised in this country [Never mind EUROPE!]
and entre nous I think Momma Biddle would be shocked if her
niece dashed up to the big city to meet Giray's plane and
just stayed at any hotel. I know you don't have your apart-
ment there any more, and if you did, I'd ask for a bed or
cot or anything for my ewe lamb for you have always been so
swell about helping inns out, and Kathy too, in past years.
But since you haven't, and Rose knows the city well, I just
thought that maybe she had some suggestion about a nice,
dull place for a jeunne fille to stay. Of course the "beau"
is sitting pretty, he doesn't have to worry as he always
lands up at the St. Regis!
I think the affair is waxing very serious and now I sort of
wish that Armant [who likegthe guy tremendously] had al-
lowed him to give him a lot of facts about himself, his
family, reason for divorce, etc. when he had a long talk
with him. But since Kathy had said she was not at that
time at all sure of herself regarding him, Armant felt it
was not the time to ask worldsof personal, leading ques-
tions. After David took me to lunch and "declared himself"
he wanted to know if there was any use his talking to Armant
and I said no, thats too premature, but anyway his last
night here he did seek Armant out and Armant told him in the
final analysis its completely up to Kathy and only time
would tell, etc. etc. Thats very true, but since me misses
David so she says, a great deal, and he is being the very
faithful, ardent suitor, I sort of wish before Kathy plans
a lot and "dreams" rosy "dreams" that if there is anything
against the man, that we knew it before she gets pretty far
in her plans and "dreamings." Oh well, somehow we shall
see what we shall see. David met Momma for lunch soon after
he left here and told her all [his hopes] and I think she likes and ad-
mires him very much, Also, she thought it a good idea for
Kathy to come up to Andalusia to visit ard I quite agree
that the more she sees of the man the more will she know her
[End Page 2]
3.
own mind, one way or the other. Dvid bought a car in
New York to take delivery of in March and that is what
they plan to motor down to New Orleans in. Believe me a
long motor trip is the acid test. Kathy and a flame from
Cincinnati [who came down here to see her last June, fresh
out of Princeton] drove over to Armstrong, Tex. and that
dusty trip on the Texas Highways really put the skids on
the GREAT romance! Katy said he then proved he had no
sense of humor, was a bum sport about little travel in-
conveniences and what the merry hell, she never wanted to
see him again. So Armant told her she'd better not try
motoring with the newest heart beat and she said she may
as well find out what sort of a motor bug he was for she
expects to do a lot of motoring the rest of her life. She
is wild to get Miss Charlotte's reaction to him and I can
can't think of a better person to give him the once over,
other than Armant, the latter being a marvelous judge of
human nature.
David is a very thoughtful person, or so he seems. Beau-
tiful red roses each week with a personal note in each
big box, several letters a week, and a phone call each
week from London until he left for Nairobi. Two days ago
he phoned from Nairobi and such excitement when Kathy got
a call from darkest Africa!He sent her the most beautiful
leather fitted week-end case I ever saw, for Christmas,
so she says she just HAS to take a trip, now! Meaning
when he returns in March, to New York and Andalusia. Essie
eyes the weekly roses the stunning leather fitted case
and answers Overseas Operators and sighs deeply saying
"Mr. David SHO DOES know how to court!" He told Kathy he
felt very guilty [because of the critical world situation [and] war threat] taking a safari of 3 weeks now but that
He had to go to Johannesburg on business anyway and on
the safari will be two of his associates in the office in
Johannesburg and that they could only afford to go if he
went, so apparently he promised them the hunt long ago.
He has cut the time in short however, by half, so I don't
imagine a 3 weeks hunt would yield"beaucoup l'elephants"
as Sidney used to say, but I don't know about such things.
yall I know is about wild turkeys. Anne brought me two
fat ones she had shot thru the neck and her groom told me
proudly that she is a mighty fine shot. Ah me, from ele-
phants to wild turkeys at 6333. Anne is thinner than she
was last April tho she isn't exactly cadaverous looking I
must admit. She and Tobin are the most blissfully happy
young couple I have seen in a long time, and I hope my
second-born ends up just as happy. By the way, don't
bother about that O-- help I told you I mignt ask in an
extremity. To be in with its too much to ask of you [get-
ting inside info.] re David,and secondly I think Armant
is making inquiries via some channels, or will soon, and
if all else fails and we do not find out enough, I may
[End Page 3]
4.
later on have to ask you to help me track down some vital
facts if possible. I promise not to ask if I can help it.
In the meantime, do you happen to have any close friends in
London who might make a discreet inquiry here and there?
Please don't say to anyone, even Armant, that I even asked
that, but I was just wondering. Momma Biddle wrote that
Charlie would be glad to write a Major somebody in London
who knows David and ask questions but Armant said no, it was
not fair to bother Charlie with this, that its our respon-
sibility [[to] find things out] and he thought we were the ores
go see it thru. Actually I think he is right, its our "head-
ache." I sincerely believe we will not find out anything
adverse, but still, I'd like to know this and that. Apparent
ly David is trying to make it as easy for us as possible as
he carefully told Armant the name of this friend and that
in New York, and wrote a letter to Armant upon reaching Lon-
don on his office stationery which gave all sorts of names 
of branch offices and managers of said branches. And, too, 
as Is aid, he did offer to tell Armant everything and give
him references when he was here, but Armant said"this is not
the time." Please destroy this letter Gertie pronto, and
don't say much about it to a soul, if anything at all. I
wouldn't want Kathy to know I have discussed it so fully
even though you and Momma are the only ones I have [really] discussed
it with, or ever intend to, other than Armant. I will keep
you and Momma posted on what we do, or do not, find out. [I
told Morris the romance was blossoming but not many details or anything about our inquiries for instance]
Forgive such an awful, long winded billet-doux, but you 
were so swell and helpful when you were here, and tactfully
got some facts to help me then, and met the man, so I
thought I'd bring you up to date and tell you whats on Ar-
mants and my minds!
Lots and lots of love, and thank you Gertie darling for a
most wonderful lot of Christmas gifts to the family, and
ALSO for those lovely dresses which came before the holidays
and which are so helpful. I assure you Kathy is planning on
taking two of them on the great jaunt to New York to meet
the "beau." 
Devotedly,
Olive
[End Page 4]
